children.name: to do things that need doing
deal with
children.definition: to decide what needs to be done and make sure that it is done: giải quyết , xử lý
examples: ▪ Who is dealing with the accommodation arrangements for the conference?
▪ I spend most of my working day dealing with customer inquiries.
▪ I’m sorry I’m late. I had an urgent call to deal with.

children.name: see to
children.definition: /attend to to deal with all the practical details of sth that needs to be done or organized: giải quyết , xử lý
examples: I’ll join you later - there are a few things I need to see to at the office first.
My brother attended to all the funeral arrangements.
You’d better get someone to see to that leaking pipe
see to it that
I’ll see to it that everything is ready on the day.

children.name: take care of
children.definition: to make sure that arrangements are made or work iscompleted, especially when you do this forsbelseso that they do not need to worry about it: giải quyết, xử lý (cho ai)
examples: My secretary will take care of the details.
Shall I take care of your mail for you while you are away?
it/everything is taken care of sbhas dealt with it for you
Don’t worry about your passport and visa - it’s all taken care of.

children.name: leave it to me
children.definition: spokensay this to tell sb that you will be responsible for making arrangements or for doing sth that needs doing: để đó cho tôi
examples: ‘We need to make sure the others know where we’ll be meeting.’
‘Leave it to me. I’ll phone them when I get home.’

children.name: process
children.definition: if an organization such as a government department processes a letter, an official document, or formal process etc, it deals with it: xử lí
examples: You should allow two weeks for your visa application to be processed.
Computers have given banks the power to process millions of transactions a day.

children.name: follow up
children.definition: UK /follow up onUS B2  to take further action in order to deal with a complaint, request, letter etc: xử lí sau, giải quyết sau
examples: ▪ I got your e-mail but I’m afraid I forgot to follow it up.
▪ Our rule is that the complaints department must follow up a letter within two days.
▪ Following up on recommendations made last year, the president called for the more efficient use of resources.

children.name: to deal with a problem or difficult situation
tackle
children.definition: tobeginto deal with a problem in adeterminedway, especially a big or complicated problem: giải quyết, xử lí
examples: ▪ Many schools are now trying to tackle the problem of drug abuse.
▪ The new laws are aimed at tackling unemployment.
tackle sth head ondeal with sth in a direct and determined way trực tiếp xử lí
▪ Police forces in the area are trying to tackle car crime head on.

children.name: handle
children.definition: to deal with a problem or a difficult situation, especially in aneffectiveorconfidentway: giải quyết, đối phó, xử lí
examples: ▪ There were a few problems, but nothing I couldn’t handle.
▪ A lot of people find it difficult to handle criticism.
handle sth well/badly
▪ The whole situation has been very badly handled.
▪ It’s her first year as a doctor, but she is handling the pressures of the job very well.

children.name: sort out
children.definition: especially UK to deal with small but difficult problems that are causing trouble or preventing you from doing sth: giải quyết, đối phó, xử lí
examples: ▪ I spent the weekend sorting out my tax affairs.
▪ We’ll have to sort your immigration status out before we can offer you a job.
sort yourself outdeal with any personal problems you have : giải quyết những vấn đề riêng tư
▪ I decided to take a week’s holiday to try and sort myself out.

children.name: grapple with
children.definition: to try hard to deal with a difficult problem or situation, especially for a long time: vật lộn với
examples: ▪ The authorities have been grappling with the problem for a decade, but cars still choke the streets in the rush hour.
▪ There is no environmental policy in a country that is still grappling with increasing poverty.

children.name: take the bull by the horns
children.definition: to deal with a difficult situation or problem in a quick, confident, and determined way: đương đầu với khó khăn
examples: Helena decided to take the bull by the horns and organize the show herself.

children.name: when there are difficult problems that you must deal with
face
children.definition: if you face a difficult problem or duty, or it faces you, you must deal with it: đối mặt
examples: ▪ Latin America faces a growing debt problem.
▪ McManus knew he was facing the biggest challenge of his career.
▪ The new administration faces the difficult task of rebuilding the country’s economy.
be faced with/by sth
▪ He was faced with the task of breaking the bad news to the boy’s relatives.

children.name: confront
children.definition: be ed with/by if you are confronted with/by a difficult problem, you must deal with it: đương đầu
examples: Nurses are confronted with life-or-death situations on a daily basis.
He remembered when he was first confronted by the racial realities of living in South Africa.
Customers are confronted with a bewildering amount of choice.

children.name: contend with
children.definition: have to  to have to deal with a problem or several problems, especially when you are already in a difficult situation: đấu tranh, đương đầu
examples: The chairman also had to contend with divisions among the committee members.
Rescuers were having to contend with cold weather, snow and ice.

children.name: face up to
children.definition: to accept and deal with an unpleasant fact or sth difficult instead of ignoring it: đối mặt với
examples: ▪ The Principal accused parents of not facing up to their responsibilities.
face up to doing sth
▪ It’s time the government faced up to spending more on health and education.
face up to things
▪ You should face up to things, not just pretend that nothing’s happening.

children.name: reckon with
children.definition: have sb/sth to  to be in a position where you must deal with sb/sth so difficult or powerful that you might not succeed: đương đầu, đối phó
examples: You’ll have the boss to reckon with if you go home this early.
Anyone attempting to invade the country will have to reckon with the peacekeeping force.

children.name: to deal with a difficult situation in a particular way
treat
children.definition: to deal with sb/sth in a particular way and with a particular attitude: xử lí
examples: ▪ The school are treating this matter very seriously.
treat sb/sth lightlynot seriously or severely
▪ No one would suggest that sex offenders should be treated lightly.
treat something as something
▪ The company treats training as a continuous part of career development.
▪ Police say that her death is being treated as suspicious.

children.name: play
children.definition: /play it to deal with a situation by behaving in the way you think will be best in order to achieve the result that you want: giải quyết
examples: ▪ Have you decided how you want to play it?
play it well/carefully/steady etc
▪ You can get exactly what you want if you play it carefully.
play (it) safenot take any risks
▪ In the run-up to the election, politicians in both parties just wanted to play it safe.
play (it) straightdo something or deal with someone in a direct honest way
▪ Some of the people involved in the competition, were not playing it straight.
▪ ‘Play straight with me or I’ll kill you,’ he hissed.
play it coolbehave as though you do not care about sb/sth :
▪ She would not show him how upset she was. It was always smarter to play it cool.
play it by eardecide what to do as the situation develops tùy cơ ứng biến
▪ ‘What’ll you do if he asks you?’ ‘I’m not sure, I’ll play it by ear.’

children.name: approach
children.definition: to begin to deal with a difficult situation in a particular way or with a particular attitude: giải quyết, tiếp cận
examples: I don’t think refusing to negotiate is the right way to approach this problem.
Try to relax before the exam, and you’ll approach it in a better frame of mind.

children.name: a particular way of dealing with sth
course
children.definition: / course of action an action or several actions which could be taken in order to deal with a particular situation: hướng hành động
examples: One possible course of action is to increase taxes on alcohol and tobacco.
Jim didn’t want to start an argument, so agreeing seemed to be the safest course.

children.name: approach
children.definition: a particular way of dealing with a problem, difficult situation, or job: hướng tiếp cận
examples: ▪ The company needs to adopt a much more radical approach.
approach to
▪ Each of the delegates suggested a different approach to the problem.

children.name: option
children.definition: /ˈɒpʃənǁˈɑːp-/  one of several ways that you could choose in order to deal with a problem or a difficult situation: lựa chọn
examples: ▪ Working full-time may not be your best option.
▪ What other options do I have?
only optionthe only thing you can do
▪ Our only option now is to contact the police.
no optionno other way of dealing with something
▪ These people have no option but to take low-paid unattractive work.
environmental/nuclear/political etc option
▪ As for replacement fuels, many people do not like to contemplate the nuclear option.

children.name: your best bet
children.definition: spoken the best way of dealing with sth: sự lựa chọn tốt nhất
examples: ▪ For getting around the city centre, a bicycle’s your best bet.
somebody’s best bet is to do something
▪ We decided that our best bet was to leave him where he was and go and get help.

children.name: do
children.definition: verbdid,doneDEAL WITHgiả quyết, xử lí
examples: [ T ] to deal with; to be responsible for
_Lucia is going to do the publicity for the school play.
_If they ask any awkward questions, just let me do the talking.

children.name: get on
children.definition: phrasal verbMANAGE xoay sở với
examples: mainlyUK(mainly USget along) to manage or deal with a situation, especially successfully
_How are you getting on in your new flat?
_We're getting on quite wellwiththe decorating.

children.name: face
children.definition: verbDEAL WITHđối diện, đương đầuvới
examples: [ T ] to accept that something unpleasant is true and start to deal with the situation
_I think Phil has to facethe fact thatshe no longer loves him.
_We have to facefactshere - we simply don't have enough money.
_He's dying but he refuses to facethe truth.

children.name: take over
children.definition: take(sth)overphrasal verbSTART DOING
examples: to start doing a job or being responsible for something that another person did or had responsibility for before
_He took overfromthe previous headmaster in February.
_She took overasmanager two weeks ago.
_Colin Lamb has taken over responsibility for this project.

children.name: address
children.definition: verbDEAL WITH
examples: to give attention to or deal with a matter or problem
_Theissueof funding has yet to be addressed.

children.name: confront
children.definition: verb
examples: to face, meet or deal with a difficult situation or person
_As she left the court, she was confrontedbyangry crowds who tried to block her way.
_It's an issue we'll have to confront at some point, no matter how unpleasant it is.
_I thought I would remain calm, but
_when I was confrontedwith/bythe TV camera, I became very nervous.
